stream_context.summary: Kaze primarily worked on modeling and texturing several parts of the game's overworld, focusing on a specific cave area. During the stream, he struggled to recall a key mission idea for the cave, eventually remembering it with help from chat. He also spent time refining level design to make it less punishing for players, discussed his YouTube content strategy and sponsorship deals, and reminisced about his history with Super Smash Bros. Melee.

development_findings.summary: The game is approaching a releasable state, but Kaze wants to dedicate an undefined amount of time to polishing it further.
development_findings.quote: we're almost in a state Where we would be able to just release the game. But there is still some polishing I want to do.

development_findings.summary: Kaze estimates the overworld is about 30% complete, having finished the basic layout for the first four of fourteen total sections.
development_findings.quote: The overworld I would say is maybe 30% done.

development_findings.summary: Kaze identified a fall into a water pit as being overly punishing and redesigned the area by adding small platforms to make recovery less frustrating for the player.
development_findings.quote: Oh my god, if I fell in here I would lose it. I would lose my cool. We can't have this in the game.

development_findings.summary: A forgotten mission idea for a cave in the overworld was recovered during the stream; it involves carrying a crystal to reveal a temporary path.
development_findings.quote: so the idea was there would be a crystal here and while you hold the crystal a path around mario appears and you can only attack with the path while you are holding the crystal

development_findings.summary: Kaze is recruiting beta testers via a Google Form, seeking feedback on the general gameplay experience rather than formal bug hunting.
development_findings.quote: It's gameplay testing. Not bug testing. So I want you to just play the game As you normally would.

development_findings.summary: A design feature connects the overworld to a course via a 'one-way mirror' effect, making the world feel more interconnected.
development_findings.quote: in Course 3, there is this mirror here that reflects the level back at you, and then in the overworld, there is this where you can look through the mirror.

development_findings.summary: Kaze encountered a graphical bug related to the underlying 'f3d_parser' and has decided to wait for the decompilation community to provide a fix rather than tackling it himself.
development_findings.quote: that's still a bug in first 64, not much I can do about it. I can just wait for them to fix it.

development_findings.summary: The game will feature post-game content for replayability, which Kaze describes as being 'something like green stars'.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is making more YouTube videos out of financial necessity to support his family, a decision driven by pragmatism.
context_findings.quote: I need to feed my family. It sounds so depressing. But it is what it is.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is experiencing significant stress from an unresolved tax issue with the German authorities (Finansamt), stemming from a non-responsive tax advisor he hired while living there.
context_findings.quote: I am in this fucked up situation. Where I think I did everything right. But I have no proof for it. And there's no way for me to find out.

context_findings.summary: Reflecting on his tax issues, Kaze regrets relying on a professional instead of taking the time to understand the system himself, a lesson he learned after moving to Canada.
context_findings.quote: I should have just informed myself. Instead of paying some professional To do it for me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes Mario 64 hacks are easier to make enjoyable because the core movement mechanics are inherently fun, whereas Zelda hacks require comprehensive design of puzzles and story, which is much more difficult to execute well.
context_findings.quote: When you make a Mario 64 hack you don't have to really design the game... When you make a Zelda hack you have to actually design the puzzles, the story, everything. It is so much harder to actually make a fun Zelda game.

context_findings.summary: Despite working on a large-scale project himself, Kaze advocates for new developers to begin with smaller, more manageable projects.
context_findings.quote: I would always recommend everyone to start with a bunch of small projects. It is a much more healthy approach.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that realizing one's own game has significant flaws through playtesting is a crucial and humbling experience for every game designer.
context_findings.quote: I think this is something every game designer has to go through. The harsh wake up call of like, oh, actually, my game sucks.

context_findings.summary: When discussing Super Smash Bros. Melee, Kaze described his mindset as aiming for perfection and complete mastery over a character's technical skills, which influenced his character choice (Marth over the more technically demanding Fox).
context_findings.quote: I am the type of player, I want to play perfect.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is deliberately avoiding Patreon for beta test recruitment due to concerns about potential legal trouble.
Kaze anticipates that his next major endeavor after Return to Yoshi's Island will be developing a game with his own original intellectual property.
context_findings.quote: It is more likely that after RTY I have to make my own games, my own IP entirely, which I have ideas for.

biobak.summary: Biobak has reportedly completed the artwork and texturing for Course 2.
biobak.quote: I think Biobak also finished course 2.

biobak.summary: Biobak is responsible for the final color palettes and texture work, with Kaze doing placeholder work on stream.
biobak.quote: we're not gonna worry too much about color right now because Biobak is doing a lot of this anyway.

biobak.summary: Kaze believes Biobak has finished a rework of the textures for Course 3, noting that a progress tracker showed it at 75% two weeks prior.

key_stories.title: The Forgotten Star Mission
key_stories.summary: Kaze forgot a crucial mission idea for an area he was building. After failing to find it in his archives, a viewer's comment reminded him of the concept, allowing development to proceed.
key_stories.challenge: While working on a cave in the overworld, Kaze realized he had completely forgotten the specific star mission that was planned for the area and hadn't written it down.
key_stories.process: Kaze first tried to find the idea by scrubbing through old VODs of his streams without success. He was about to put the area on hold until a viewer in chat provided the keyword that helped him remember the mission.
key_stories.outcome: A chatter reminded Kaze of the key concept ('gargoyle'), which triggered his memory of the 'crystal holding' mission. He was able to document the idea and refine it on the spot, overcoming the creative block.
key_stories.key_quote: oh that's the idea okay so the idea was there would be a crystal here and while you hold the crystal a path around mario appears

key_stories.title: Fixing the Frustration Pit
key_stories.summary: Kaze found a section of the level to be overly punishing. He decided it was bad design and immediately created a solution to make it less frustrating, demonstrating his player-focused design philosophy.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze identified a deep water pit in the overworld that would be extremely frustrating and punishing for players to fall into, which he deemed unacceptable for the game's design.
key_stories.process: Upon realizing the negative player experience, Kaze vocalized his frustration from a player's perspective. He then brainstormed a simple, effective solution and began modeling the new platforms to solve the issue.
key_stories.outcome: He immediately designed and implemented a solution: adding a series of small, easy-to-use platforms that allow the player to quickly get back to the main path, reducing the penalty for a fall significantly.
key_stories.key_quote: Oh my god, if I fell in here I would lose it. I would lose my cool. We can't have this in the game.

key_stories.title: The German Tax Nightmare
key_stories.summary: Kaze shared his ongoing struggle with the German tax authority. A professional he hired has become unresponsive, leaving him in a stressful limbo where he can't confirm if his significant tax obligations have been properly settled.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze is dealing with a significant, unresolved tax problem originating from his time living in Germany, which is causing him considerable stress now that he's in Canada.
key_stories.process: He hired a professional tax advisor in Germany on his parents' recommendation. However, an issue arose, and now the advisor is not communicating, leaving Kaze without proof of payment or resolution and unable to get the $4000 he is owed back.
key_stories.outcome: The situation remains unresolved. Kaze is left in a state of anxiety and uncertainty, unable to get confirmation from his unresponsive tax advisor or contact the German tax office directly.
key_stories.key_quote: I am in this fucked up situation. Where I think I did everything right. But I have no proof for it. And there's no way for me to find out.

Does the scope of the polishing phase depend on feedback from the beta testers?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions his financial reality, stating he creates YouTube content to 'feed his family' and discusses his flat-rate sponsorship model in detail.

Does the need to secure sponsorships and create videos influence the development timeline or scope of Return to Yoshi's Island?
